My Thoughts on Dragon's Dogma 2

The first Dragon's Dogma was this weird cult classic everyone loved for what it could've been as much as what it was. Now, over a decade later, Capcom finally dropped the sequel. It's a mixed bagâ€”better in some ways, frustrating in others.

The Good: Beauty, Combat, and World Design

The game is incredibly beautifulâ€”it might genuinely be one of the best-looking game for me. The lighting is amazing, and the visual sharpness showcases how effective Capcomâ€™s game engine is.

On PC, the combat and controls are vastly improved over the first game, feeling much smoother and more satisfying. The core gameplay loop is phenomenal: the combat is weighty, strategic, and mechanically satisfying. I love the exploration and the vocation system, which lets you freely unlock and switch classes on a whim, keeping every playthrough fresh.

A Masterclass in Open-World Design

Dragon's Dogma 2â€™s open-world design is a masterclass and what truly sets it apart. The world feels real in a way most RPGs don't attempt. It has genuine geography, where shortcuts loop back to main roads and caves open into unexpected valleysâ€”everything connects. You navigate by landmarks, not by a minimap, forcing you to remember the structure of the world.

The atmosphere is thick, and the night is a threat, not just a visual filter. You must plan journeys, bring lanterns, and avoid certain areas after dark, adding a crucial layer of immersion.

The Pawn System

The Pawn system remains one of the series' purest strokes of genius. It creates a powerful sense of community and is essentially a brilliant multiplayer element without the usual hassle. Your AI companions are noticeably smarter and more helpful, learning enemy weaknesses, sharing knowledge, and even guiding you to hidden locations. Their chatter also has more variety, adding to their personality.

And yeah, character creation actually matters mechanicallyâ€”your size and gender affect gameplay. More RPGs should do this.

The Problems

Despite all the brilliance, Dragon's Dogma 2 launched with major bugs and performance hiccups. If your PC isn't a "beast," you might need to upgrade or grab a console, as the game will humble it. I am personally playing at 30fps and genuinely hope an optimization patch arrives soon.

The game also initially faced criticism for its microtransactions. However, my advice is to avoid them completely. The world is rich enough that if you explore thoroughly, you can find all the necessary items in the open world, making purchases unnecessary.

Thankfully, updates have fixed most of the major issues. The game's in much better shape now than it was at release.

Worth the Wait

This game has a lot of potential, and I wish Capcom could see that and do more with it. 

At it's core, it's a pretty good game. The combat is, from a technical perspective, truly impressive, with the way you can dynamically climb enemies, and the way physical mass and momentum are important factors. The pawn system is a really cool concept, my only gripe being that I feel like it wasn't used to its full potential.

The game world is pretty interesting, with a variety of different locations, most of which are pretty well hidden. I still remember one time, stumbling upon an elf village after running for my life from a minotaur, and going "I didn't even know elves were a thing in this game". Or the time I fought a griffin, climbed on top of it, and it decided to flee while I was on it's back, so I had to barely hang on while it flew back to it's nest. And when I'd finally dealt with it, realised the only way back to civilisation was through a creepy swamp filled with undead, that was dark enough to look like night time while you travelled though it, and that I doubt I would have found if the griffin hadn't basically kidnapped me.

Overall, yeah the game can be a little repetitive at times, or the pawns can be VERY annoying with their habit of repeating the same tips you've heard a million times, but the game is pretty good as a whole. Also, I haven't mentioned the story much, since I pulled a Skyrim and got distracted, and only did little bits here and there, the end result being that I didn't know what was going on half the time. It didn't seem like something that was award winning, but it wasn't too bad either. Overall, definitely a 7/10, though if they added multiplayer Co-op, it could easily be an 8/10.

So, let's get this out of the way at the start: if you expect DD2 to be better in every aspect as a sequel you will be disappointed because it's not. Some things are better than the first one, some things are worse.

 I played DD:DA for hundreds of hours on my Xbox and my Playstation, the number of my runs is probably close to the three digits and, still, I find this game to be a more than valid sequel. Also, played DD2 on XboxSX.

[h3] What it does better [/h3]

+Graphically wise it's very good, a phenomenal upgrade on the first one.
+Weapons, especially the heavier ones, express their weight beautifully in every fight. You will frequently send goblins flying with your greatswords (or ''hunks of metal''...).
+Exploring was already fun in DD:DA, this time around it's even better, I felt like there was a bit more verticality in the world.
+The beast climbing mechanic has been revamped to be more responsive.
+One of the best, if not the actual best, character creators up to date (Dragon Age WokeGuard should learn a thing or two...).
+Your harem of female pawns will look great.
+Your harem of male pawns will look great.

[h3] What it does worse [/h3]

-less enemy variety.
-less armor and weapons variety, also no more double layering for armors.
-the main quest, at the start, feels a bit sluggish and at the end seems a little rushed.
-in DDDA you could employ 8 skills for each class, in DD2, for some reason, this got halved to 4, 3 if you take the Warfarer class and put ''Rearmament'' as a quick skill (very bad decision, I must say, but probably mods can work around this issue).
 
 As I said, it's not better in every way but other reviews have been too harsh in my opinion. It's still Dragon's Dogma and whether you like it or not, there's no other game quite like it so I for one was happy with it, even with its shortcomings. 

 Story wise it's not that Blockbuster narrative pearl to behold, but DDDA wasn't either. You play this game for its feeling of living an odyssey, the story and quests are just an alibi to take the next step out of the city and its adventures.

 Also, people whined about ''microtransactions''. TL;DR: If Steam had a "mid" rating I'd give DD2 that, but if you have to choose then go play the first one instead. Yes the oxcart mission at the beginning is possibly one of the worst introductions to any game ever but I promise you'll have a better time there than here. If you do decide to get this then go in with the understanding that the combat is quite literally the thing propping the entire game up.

I'm going to get the good out of the way first, because there is good here:
-Combat! Fighting is the core of the game, and fighting feels really good! Hits are meaty, combos are flashy, every class gets to be OP, overall fighting things is good fun and that's good because you'll be doing a lot of it. I'd go so far as to say that the combat is good enough that it propped the entire game up all on it's own. I'm gonna do a fair bit of griping in a minute so let that be a testament to how good fighting things feels, that despite my growing misgivings I played all the way through to keep messing around with the combat.
-Character and pawn customization! It was very fun making a pair of freakshows to wander around the map and murder everything that dared to move!
-The pawn system as a whole is still very fun, and you can't help but get attached to your personal buddy as you travel around.
-Much better early game than the first game, you can kinda just get right into it the moment the tutorial is over.
-If you're into it, there's plenty of ways to do challenge runs or even speed runs of the game once you know it's ins and outs a little better, for that little bit of replay value.

And now for the cons:
-Oh my god the optimization is bad. Every review saying that the optimization is bad is somehow underselling it.
-You get too strong too fast. Like, in DD1 you definitely get to a point where you're blitzing through health bars and treating larger enemies like mild inconveniences, but it takes a little bit to get there. I was at that point here well before I ever saw the second half of the map. Now, granted, this may have been partly my own fault for going slightly out of my way to rank up the various classes to get augments I wanted, but hitting those extremes of power so early on still feels really weird when you wind up doing it on accident.
-Way, WAY less enemy variety than the first game. Do you enjoy fighting goblins, saurians, and harpies? You'd better because that's the majority of what you'll be dealing with. Every once in a while you'll be treated to a cyclops. If you've been really good maybe an ogre or a griffon will show up to get absolutely demolished. Golems exist too I guess, sometimes. Chimeras are so rare I think I can count on one hand how many I dealt with (4). Minotaurs, zombies and skeletons are so sparse I'd often get surprised because I would forget they exist (despite being more common than chimeras). Oh yeah there's also the Medusa from the beginning of the game as well. I literally never fought her again but she's around apparently. It's genuinely frustrating when the combat feels so good but the enemies don't change in any meaningful way for the whole game. 
-In a brave and absolutely flabbergasting decision, the game does not have a single good quest. Not one. Not a single one. No good rewards either, before you get ahead of yourself. "But the ones that unlock Dwarven Smithing!" I hear some of you say, and to that I say: didn't need it. Didn't upgrade a single piece of gear even once for the whole game. It was still a curbstomp. "But the Sphinx quests!" others may reply. A series of fetch quests with rewards ranging from "I might use this once or twice" to "literally forgot it existed within seconds of getting it". The quests, be they main or side, are stunningly boring. It's genuinely impressive actually, that they managed to make an entire action RPG and not one worthwhile quest.
-The fight with the dragon is LAME compared to the first game. Don't get me wrong, by the time you fight the dragon in the first game you're geared and ready to thrash it, but there's a gravitas and a spectacle to it. You've been working all the way up to that point and by god you got a fight that reflected that. The dragon fight here comes across as an afterthought, so not only is it easy, it's also anticlimactic.
-Speaking of anticlimactic, fights with most large enemies quickly become anticlimactic. The first time you fight a chimera in the first game (outside of the prologue), it's like a whole boss battle. It gets it's own arena and everything. The first time I fought a chimera in this it literally died off screen. I was busy culling the local goblin population and my pawns beat the snot out of it around the corner while I wasn't looking. Don't get me wrong, the change of pace in having to deal with a large enemy is always welcome, but there's very little fanfare and often equally little threat. 

And lastly the mid:
-Exploration is there. Sometimes you'll come across some decent gear and save yourself some money, or maybe you'll find a Seeker's Token (the collectible doodad of the game). Most of the time it's just more healing items and crafting materials you'll stash away for that rainy day that never comes.
-All the classes get to be OP but not every class gets to be OP in a way that's fun. The easiest example of this is the Trickster class. If you're playing Trickster correctly, you and your pawns are functionally immortal and should be able to beat every encounter. Unfortunately, as Trickster doesn't get to do damage themselves, this usually means relying on the pawns to eventually come to the correct decision of how to go about beating said encounters. Depending on your chosen pawns (which should all be damage dealers because you're playing Trickster correctly), this can either take twice as long as doing it yourself as a different class or up to six times as long as doing it yourself as a different class. Yeah, it works, and it's powerful, but it's also really really boring. Thief and Magick Archer are also both a touch overtuned to the point of making them boring to play as imo, but at least with those classes you still get to do things other than wait for the game to finish playing itself.
-It doesn't take too long to start seeing how static the encounters are out on the map. You can use this to your advantage if you decide you really want to grind out a specific monster material or just want to fight a specific thing for the sake of it, but generally it just means you know exactly how many goblin/saurian/harpy fights are between Point A and Point B instead of having the hope of fighting literally anything else.

If the first game was a sneaky 8/10 this is a dissapointing 6/10. It's not BAD, I can't in good conscience say it's bad when I played all the way through and mostly had a good time. Unfortunately the lack of enemy variety, challenge, and ANY good quests at all really just kneecaps the whole experience.

[h1] Dragon's Dogma 2 - A Masterclass in Frustration [/h1]
[b] Summary: [/b] Intentionally punishing design ruins the experience for completionists and casual players alike.
[hr][/hr]
Dragon's Dogma 2 has amazing combat and a beautiful world, but every positive is overshadowed by its infuriating design choices. The game actively punishes players for not knowing arbitrary "rules" that are never explained.
Here are the critical flaws that made my playthrough a miserable experience:
[h3] Permanent Quest Failure Without Warning[/h3]
Major quests, including those that unlock the best skills and items (like the Sorcerer's Maelstrom), can be permanently failed or locked out if you miss an obscure trigger, talk to the wrong NPC first, or simply progress the main story at the intended pace. There are no clear quest markers or "failure" warnings; things just disappear from your log or become permanently discontinued.
[h3] Arbitrary NPC Behavior[/h3]
NPCs follow rigid routines that can be easily disrupted by random events (like a monster killing a crucial merchant) or bugs (like an attendant never spawning for a main romance quest), making complex quests impossible to complete. The game offers no reliable way to fix this other than a single, punishing save file.
[h3] Zero Handholding[/h3]
The game intends for you to figure things out, but provides zero indication of what to do next. You are forced to rely on external guides or stumble around hoping for a random event to trigger, which wastes hours of time.
[h3] Unforgiving Save System[/h3]
The single-save system means one mistake (like an infected pawn or a bad quest decision) can ruin an entire playthrough, forcing a restart or living with the permanent, negative consequences.
Dragon's Dogma 2 is a game that values "fun over function," but the fun is quickly lost when a single uncommunicated rule permanently locks you out of the experience you paid for. I cannot recommend this game to anyone who values completing content or having a fair, guided experience.

Right off the top, this review is based on initial impressions, not hours worth of gameplay. I ended up returning it for a refund because of performance and stability issues, which I'll touch on at the end of the review.

I love, love, LOVE the original Dragon's Dogma and Dark Arisen games! But my initial impressions is that Dragon Dogma 2 is a game based on Dragon's Dogma (pawn system, lore, etc), but it's [u]not[/u] Dragon's Dogma. What I mean is, it feels very clunky and "wooden" compared to the fun and fluid game that is original DD. Combat feels way more clunky to me, and the world feels "dull". I can't fully put my finger on why, but it just doesn't feel like DD. I've been playing another game called Enshrouded, and it feels more like original Dragon's Dogma from a combat and "colorful world" perspect than this official Capcom game.

I bought the game on sale for $30, and while the main reason I refunded it was due to technical issues, had this game engaged me in the first two hours of play, I might have kept it with the hope of fixing those issues. But first impressions matter, and I'm not so sure I would have gotten $30 of enjoyment out of this game even if I could play it for more than 10 minutes at a time without it crashing.

Now let's talk about those issues - the graphic quality of this game does NOT justify the low framerates and high system requirements! It just doesn't look that good. I've got other games in my library that look WAY better than this, that run fluidly at 60 fps on my gaming rig. Obviously it looks better than DD1, but that was originally a PS3 game with bare-minimum requirements. Now I could have easily forgiven the lackluster graphics of DD2 if it was rock-stable at 60+ fps, but what we have is "okayish" graphics with horrible performance and crazy system requirements. I'm not impressed with this at all. Again, I've got dozens of other titles that do way more with way less.

As someone who loves DD and DD:DA, I'm disappointed that I couldn't get into DD2. Maybe I'll try again someday when I have a top-tier gaming rig and this title is on sale for $20 or less, and maybe, after hours of gameplay, it'll grow on me. I'll update this review if that happens. But until then, I can't recommend it.

I want to like this game, I really do. But tragically it is another Triple A title that values appearance over functionality, and prioritizes a bizarely faulty sense of cinema over player experience. 

NARRATIVE:
Dragon's Dogma 2 is shockingly bad at informing the player what to do, it's almost as if the writers of this game are space aliens who don't have a decent grasp of human logic or intuition. The plot is confusing and completely failed to get me invested in the story, I was frequently frustrated by vague and unhelpful quest directions, and I stopped playing when (to avoid spoilers) the game arbitrarily forces you to repeat gameplay that you've already done with no hope of a loading a save. On an immersion note, there is no real difference between the humans and cat-people, nor the people of the two regions: they all have the same anachronistic speech patterns devoid of personality, which makes them seem like cardboard cutouts of middle-school children doing their best Shakespeare impression from memory. 

GAMEPLAY
The combat is noticeably more clunky than the first game, with the player's vision obscured much more frequently. I constantly found my character stuck in animations that I couldn't even see through smoke, fire, or a monster's big hairy arse. 
The fast travel is needlessly convoluted, with ox carts ONLY departing at certain times of day and getting interrupted by monster attacks quite often. Exiting and thrilling the first time, considerably less so when you just want to get to the next town to get a quest done. Ferrystones are still in limited supply, and I didn't play far enough to know whether an Eternal Ferrystone like in the first game is unlocked at some point. Capcom clearly did not learn enough lessons from the first title, and this game somehow manages to disrespect your time even more than the first one. 

CONCLUSION:
This game has its good points, but I have to admit I'm struggling to remember any of them. Multiple times during this game I thought to myself 'I miss the first Dragon's Dogma'. Or, even worse, 'I miss Skyrim'. That is damning for a game released in 2024, to make someone nostalgic for games released in 2012 and 2011 respectively. 
In the highly unlikely event that anyone from Capcom is reading this: I know you put a lot of work into this game, and I feel bad being so negative about such a grand effort. 
But you didn't succeed: this game is not as good as the first one.

[h3][b]> First, Microtransactions and obtuse design[/b][/h3]  Yeah, they had to start by going there... I don't care if those are "not really useful in game". Poop stains and stinks. This is poop. Greedy poop. Poop that I'm pretty sure interfered in the game's design to give it space to "shine". Since there's a lot of obtuse design here, the "make things really boring and inconvenient so people think that buying microtransactions is a good idea" kind of poop.

[h3]> [b]Interesting Combat, but it's too rigid[/b][/h3]  There's a really good base here, but it was heavily brought down for, or because of, other systems, like the pawn system, since the pawns can not only take the enemy off of you, but also can get you out of control effects like waking you up. The constraints are really heavy, so you're forced to play with a party.
- ie. you only have a dodge if you play thief. If you don't? You are a sitting duck for enemy attacks and combos. It's easy to get staggered and every animation is very slow. It's surreal how combat in this feel rigid and static, like you are inside a bog.

[h3]> [b]The pawn system[/b][/h3] is the worst idea I've seen in a RPG. They are your party for adventures, but they are soulless AI husks that spoils the game for you. For exemple, if you hired the pawn of another player and they know a secret, they may just tell you about it, go find it and loot it before you can say "oh there is a treasure there?". Their whole story is "we are a soulless race of servants under your command". They are named, as a whole race, "Pawns", for God's sake...

[h3]> [b]And the story?[/b][/h3] It's generic chosen one storyline with [u]very little[/u] to offer.

[h3]> [b]Magic is cool[/b][/h3]  Yeah, mage spells are cool, but sorcerer spells are really big and flashy, so much so that it deserves a topic reserved for itself. But calling a meteor storm is really cool lol.

[h3]> [b]The world and enemies are boring[/b][/h3]
By now I'm pretty sure you noticed the pattern, the common theme of basically every facet of this game. It's soulless, boring, not memorable, and to top it off the enemy variety is low.

[h3]> [b]Performance and Optimization is really bad in general[/b][/h3]
That is about it. The recommended fix is to play locked at 30 fps, while not being much pretty, the game will draw out all the strength in your cpu lmao.

[h3]> [b]Conclusion[/b][/h3]
Good base and foundation, but bad execution. Playing this game feels like you are "alone in a crowd". Soulless companions, soulless world, soulless npcs. The interesting part of team based RPG is the personality, story and character arcs of the companions, like in Chrono Trigger, Final Fantasy, Expedition 33 and many others. Yet, in this game you don't have that. But you also don't have the "alone against the world" kind of feeling of Souls-likes either.

[b]Finishing words[/b]
To sum it up, a game that has potential dragged down by a lot of bad decisions (and some of mobile influence in the pawn system specially, I think). But I think there's some good in here. The game is poorly optimized and and average hardware will likely experience substantial fps dips in cities. It's a miracle we got a sequel since Capcom clearly couldn't care less about the IP.

Most important issue, it runs terribly. It's the same story from DDDA, but worse. Fewer equipment slots, fewer monsters, map is full of closed areas and mountains or ocean. Forced to walk winding roads forever with no danger on them. 
The game is so easy it's unbelievable and I don't mean it in an elitist way, I mean you can just throw anything at any enemy and they're going to die. You can dodge most things my walking normally around them or underneath them.

The item enhancement system is split up and frankly dumb.

The pawns are somehow even stupider than before and insist on high fiving every 2 seconds, which does something we all love, namely wrestling control of the character and camera away from you. They fight a lot worse than DDDA, I mean a lot worse. I mean 100m behind you during a fight, I mean I'm getting mauled by wolves and pressing "Help!" just causes them to cast a heal or shield summons (this does not make the wolves release you). They ignore weak spots or things like Augural Flare.

Skill slots are fewer than before and sorcerer has been gutted. Spell AOE is now useless, cast time is much much faster, but it somehow still feels worse. Spell selection is unappealing and the big spells are quest gated and missable.

The atmosphere and sense of wonder DDDA still has on the 100th time around is nonexistent.

This game is a monkey's paw wish, the embodiment of "can i copy your homework", the pinnacle of corporate greed and a slap in the face for a fanbase which has waited and asked for over a decade.

Do not buy this game unless it's 80% off or less, you probably won't play it twice. Let's pray for a BBI level of repair, otherwise this game is doomed to exist as a skidmark on Dragon's Dogmas' tidy whities.
